text: The identification of C. perfringens in the affected puppies could be related to the intestinal dysbiosis. The changes in the intestinal environment of dogs with diarrhea promote increased proliferation and transient overgrowth of enterotoxigenic strains of C. perfringens, leading to detectable amounts of enterotoxin (cpe) in the feces [30] . Frequent growth of C. perfringens was observed in the intestine of dogs with CPV infection [31] .
